sn22.68:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.68:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn22.68:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu …pe… ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn22.68:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn22.68:1.4.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhu, anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn22.68:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, give up desire for what is not-self.”

sn22.68:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.68:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.68:2.2.pli: “Rūpaṃ kho, bhante, anattā; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:2.2.eng: “Sir, form is not-self; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ anattā; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:2.6.eng: Consciousness is not-self; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:2.7.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn22.68:2.7.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn22.68:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
sn22.68:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.68:3.3.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, bhikkhu, anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:3.3.eng: Form is not-self; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:3.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:3.7.eng: Consciousness is not-self; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:3.8.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti …pe…
sn22.68:3.8.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.” …

sn22.68:3.9.pli: aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.68:3.9.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn22.69:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, anattaniyaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.

sn22.69:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.69:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.69:2.2.eng: “Sir, form doesn’t belong to self; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.69:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ anattaniyaṃ; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.69:2.6.eng: Consciousness doesn’t belong to self; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.69:2.7.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.

sn22.69:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.69:3.3.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, bhikkhu, anattaniyaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.69:3.3.eng: Form doesn’t belong to self; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.69:3.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ anattaniyaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.69:3.7.eng: Consciousness doesn’t belong to self; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.69:3.8.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti …pe…
sn22.69:3.8.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.” …

sn22.69:3.9.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn22.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you how grasping leads to anxiety, and how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.

sn22.7:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn22.7:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn22.7:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti, kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn22.7:2.1.eng: “And how does grasping lead to anxiety?
sn22.7:2.1.comm: Also at MN 138:20.1; for the erroneous reading there, see note.

sn22.7:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn22.7:2.2.eng: It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.7:2.3.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.7:2.3.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.7:2.4.pli: Tassa taṃ rūpaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.7:2.4.eng: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.7:2.5.eng: and consciousness latches on to the perishing of form.
sn22.7:2.5.comm: “Latches on to” (anuparivatti), literally, “runs around after”.

sn22.7:2.6.pli: Tassa rūpavipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn22.7:2.6.eng: Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of form, and originating in accordance with natural principles.

sn22.7:2.7.pli: Cetaso pariyādānā uttāsavā ca hoti vighātavā ca apekkhavā ca upādāya ca paritassati.
sn22.7:2.7.eng: So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping.

sn22.7:3.1.pli: Vedanaṃ attato samanupassati, vedanāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā vedanaṃ, vedanāya vā attānaṃ.

sn22.7:3.2.pli: Tassa sā vedanā vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.

sn22.7:3.4.pli: Tassa vedanāvipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.

sn22.7:3.5.pli: Cetaso pariyādānā uttāsavā ca hoti vighātavā ca apekkhavā ca upādāya ca paritassati.

sn22.7:4.2.pli: saṅkhāre attato samanupassati, saṅkhāravantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā saṅkhāre, saṅkhāresu vā attānaṃ.

sn22.7:4.3.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā vipariṇamanti aññathā honti.

sn22.7:4.5.pli: Tassa saṅkhāravipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.

sn22.7:4.6.pli: Cetaso pariyādānā uttāsavā ca hoti vighātavā ca apekkhavā ca upādāya ca paritassati.

sn22.7:5.1.pli: Viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.7:5.1.eng: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn22.7:5.2.pli: Tassa taṃ viññāṇaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.7:5.2.eng: But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.7:5.3.eng: and consciousness latches on to the perishing of consciousness.

sn22.7:5.4.pli: Tassa viññāṇavipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn22.7:5.4.eng: Anxieties occupy their mind, born of latching on to the perishing of consciousness, and originating in accordance with natural principles.

sn22.7:5.5.pli: Cetaso pariyādānā uttāsavā ca hoti vighātavā ca apekkhavā ca upādāya ca paritassati.
sn22.7:5.5.eng: So they become frightened, worried, concerned, and anxious because of grasping.

sn22.7:5.6.eng: That’s how grasping leads to anxiety.

sn22.7:6.1.eng: And how does not grasping lead to freedom from anxiety?

sn22.7:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto, sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
sn22.7:6.2.eng: It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.7:6.3.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; na attani vā rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.7:6.3.eng: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.7:6.4.pli: Tassa taṃ rūpaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.7:6.4.eng: When that form of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.7:6.5.pli: Tassa rūpavipariṇāmaññathābhāvā na rūpavipariṇāmānuparivatti viññāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.7:6.5.eng: consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of form.

sn22.7:6.6.pli: Tassa na rūpavipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn22.7:6.6.eng: Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of form and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind.

sn22.7:6.7.pli: Cetaso apariyādānā na cevuttāsavā hoti na ca vighātavā na ca apekkhavā, anupādāya ca na paritassati.
sn22.7:6.7.eng: So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping.

sn22.7:7.1.pli: Na vedanaṃ attato samanupassati, na vedanāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ; na attani vā vedanaṃ, na vedanāya vā attānaṃ.
sn22.7:7.1.eng: They don’t regard feeling as self …

sn22.7:7.2.pli: Tassa sā vedanā vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.

sn22.7:7.3.pli: Tassa vedanāvipariṇāmaññathābhāvā na vedanāvipariṇāmānuparivatti viññāṇaṃ hoti.

sn22.7:7.4.pli: Tassa na vedanāvipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.

sn22.7:7.5.pli: Cetaso apariyādānā na cevuttāsavā hoti na ca vighātavā na ca apekkhavā, anupādāya ca na paritassati.

sn22.7:8.1.pli: Na saññaṃ …pe… na saṅkhāre attato samanupassati,
sn22.7:8.1.eng: They don’t regard perception as self …

sn22.7:8.2.pli: na attani vā saṅkhāre, na saṅkhāresu vā attānaṃ.
sn22.7:8.2.eng: They don’t regard choices as self …

sn22.7:8.4.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā vipariṇamanti aññathā honti.

sn22.7:8.5.pli: Tassa saṅkhāravipariṇāmaññathābhāvā na saṅkhāravipariṇāmānuparivatti viññāṇaṃ hoti.

sn22.7:8.6.pli: Tassa na saṅkhāravipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.

sn22.7:8.7.pli: Cetaso apariyādānā na cevuttāsavā hoti na ca vighātavā na ca apekkhavā, anupādāya ca na paritassati.

sn22.7:9.1.pli: Na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ …pe…
sn22.7:9.1.eng: They don’t regard consciousness as self …

sn22.7:9.2.pli: tassa taṃ viññāṇaṃ vipariṇamati aññathā hoti.
sn22.7:9.2.eng: When that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,

sn22.7:9.3.pli: Tassa viññāṇavipariṇāmaññathābhāvā na viññāṇavipariṇāmānuparivatti viññāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.7:9.3.eng: consciousness doesn’t latch on to the perishing of consciousness.

sn22.7:9.4.pli: Tassa na viññāṇavipariṇāmānuparivattijā paritassanā dhammasamuppādā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn22.7:9.4.eng: Anxieties—born of latching on to the perishing of consciousness and originating in accordance with natural principles—don’t occupy their mind.

sn22.7:9.5.pli: Cetaso apariyādānā na cevuttāsavā hoti na ca vighātavā na ca apekkhavā, anupādāya ca na paritassati.
sn22.7:9.5.eng: So they don’t become frightened, worried, concerned, or anxious because of grasping.

sn22.7:9.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, anupādā aparitassanaṃ hotī”ti.
sn22.7:9.6.eng: That’s how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.”

sn22.70:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.70:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn22.70:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā …pe… vihareyyan”ti.
sn22.70:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn22.70:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, rajanīyasaṇṭhitaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn22.70:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, give up desire for whatever is shaped by arousal.”
sn22.70:1.4.comm: Commentary says, “shaped by the conditioned nature of desire”.

sn22.70:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.70:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.70:2.2.pli: “Rūpaṃ kho, bhante, rajanīyasaṇṭhitaṃ; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.70:2.2.eng: “Sir, form is shaped by arousal; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.70:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ rajanīyasaṇṭhitaṃ; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.70:2.6.eng: Consciousness is shaped by arousal; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.70:2.7.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn22.70:2.7.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn22.70:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
sn22.70:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.70:3.3.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, bhikkhu, rajanīyasaṇṭhitaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.70:3.3.eng: Form is shaped by arousal; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.70:3.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ rajanīyasaṇṭhitaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.70:3.7.eng: Consciousness is shaped by arousal; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.70:3.8.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti …pe…
sn22.70:3.8.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.” …

sn22.70:3.9.pli: aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.70:3.9.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn22.71:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rādho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.71:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Rādha went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn22.71:1.2.comm: The next Saṁyutta, starting with SN 23.1, features Rādha throughout. Because he was such a persistent questioner, he was said to be the foremost of those who inspire eloquent teachings (AN 1.233). This discourse is also found at SN 18:21 and SN 22:91.

sn22.71:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
sn22.71:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs?”

sn22.71:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, rādha, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn22.71:1.4.eng: “Rādha, one truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.71:1.5.eng: One truly sees any kind of feeling …

sn22.71:1.8.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ …pe… yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn22.71:1.8.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.71:1.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, rādha, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti …pe…
sn22.71:1.9.eng: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs.” …

sn22.71:1.10.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā rādho arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.71:1.10.eng: And Venerable Rādha became one of the perfected.

sn22.72:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā surādho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.72:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Surādha said to the Buddha:
sn22.72:1.2.comm: Surādha’s verses are at Thag 2.8. This discourse is also at SN 18:22 and SN 22:92.

sn22.72:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti, vidhā samatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti?
sn22.72:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed?”

sn22.72:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, surādha, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ …pe… yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādāvimutto hoti.
sn22.72:1.4.eng: “Surādha, one is freed by not grasping having truly seen any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.72:1.5.eng: One is freed by not grasping having truly seen any kind of feeling …

sn22.72:1.8.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbā vedanā …pe…
sn22.72:1.8.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.72:1.8.comm: The handling of abbreviations is corrupted here in the Burmese editions.

sn22.72:1.11.pli: sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādāvimutto hoti.

sn22.72:1.12.pli: Evaṃ kho, surādha, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti …pe…
sn22.72:1.12.eng: That’s how to know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed.” …

sn22.72:1.13.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā surādho arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.72:1.13.eng: And Venerable Surādha became one of the perfected.

sn22.73:1.2.pli: “Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano rūpassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
sn22.73:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person doesn’t truly understand the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,

sn22.73:1.6.pli: viññāṇassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.

sn22.73:1.7.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako rūpassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.73:1.7.eng: A learned noble disciple does truly understand the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,

sn22.73:1.11.pli: viññāṇassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti.

sn22.74:1.2.pli: “Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano rūpassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
sn22.74:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person doesn’t truly understand the origin, the disappearance, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,

sn22.74:1.6.pli: viññāṇassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.

sn22.74:1.7.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako rūpassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.74:1.7.eng: A learned noble disciple does truly understand the origin, the disappearance, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,

sn22.74:1.11.pli: viññāṇassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti.

sn22.75:1.2.pli: “Sutavā, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako rūpassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.75:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a learned noble disciple truly understands the origin, the disappearance, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,

sn22.75:1.6.pli: viññāṇassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti.

sn22.76:1.5.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.76:1.5.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.76:1.12.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.76:1.12.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.76:2.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi … saññāyapi … saṅkhāresupi … viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn22.76:2.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.76:2.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.76:2.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn22.76:2.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn22.76:2.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.76:2.4.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattāvāsā, yāvatā bhavaggaṃ, ete aggā, ete seṭṭhā lokasmiṃ yadidaṃ arahanto”ti.
sn22.76:2.4.eng: As far as there are abodes of sentient beings, even up until the pinnacle of existence, the perfected ones are the foremost and the best.”
sn22.76:2.4.comm: The nine “abodes of sentient beings” (sattāvāsā) are listed at (AN 9.24. The “pinnacle of existence” (bhavagga), also mentioned in passing at AN 4.75:1.3, is the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception (Vb 18:209.3, Kv 3.12:22.4).

sn22.76:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn22.76:3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn22.76:3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn22.76:4.1.eng: “Oh! How happy are the perfected ones!

sn22.76:4.2.eng: Craving is not found in them,

sn22.76:4.3.eng: the conceit ‘I am’ is cut off,

sn22.76:4.4.eng: and the net of delusion is shattered.

sn22.76:5.3.eng: nothing in the world clings to them,

sn22.76:6.2.eng: their domain is the seven good qualities.

sn22.76:7.1.comm: The seven factors of awakening (SN 46.42).

sn22.76:7.2.eng: and trained in the three trainings,

sn22.76:7.4.eng: with fear and dread given up.

sn22.76:8.1.comm: The “ten qualities of an adept” are the eight path factors plus right knowledge and right freedom (AN 10.112).

sn22.76:8.2.eng: those giants are immersed in samādhi.

sn22.76:8.3.eng: They are the best in the world,

sn22.76:8.4.eng: craving is not found in them.

sn22.76:9.2.eng: ‘This bag of bones is my last.’

sn22.76:9.4.eng: in the core of the spiritual path.

sn22.76:10.1.eng: They do not waver due to the discriminations,
sn22.76:10.1.comm: Vikampati is also used in the context of the threefold conceit at SN 1.20:23.3 = Snp 4.9:8.3 and in the verses of Mahākassapa at Thag 18.1:26.4.

sn22.76:10.3.eng: They’ve reached the level of the tamed,

sn22.76:10.4.eng: in the world, they’re the winners.

sn22.76:11.2.eng: relishing is not found in them.

sn22.76:11.4.eng: ‘The awakened are supreme in the world!’”

sn22.77:1.2.comm: This is the same as the previous, except lacking verses.
